variant.question: Why is there a limit on the full rudder deflection as airspeed -IAS- increases on transport aeroplanes?

options.text: Because full rudder deflection could create an excessive load on the structure.
Full rudder deflection is not to be limited on transport aeroplanes as airspeed increases.
To reduce the directional stability at high airspeed.
To reduce the risk of entering a spiral divergence in cruise.

variant.question: Explain why a full rudder deflection is limited on CAT transport aeroplanes as indicated airspeed increases?

options.text: A full rudder deflection could cause an excessive load on the structure of the aeroplane.
The statement is wrong since full rudder deflection is not limited with increasing airspeed.
To avoid any risk of entering a spiral during cruise flight.
To decrease the directional stability when the aeroplane is flying with high airspeeds.

variant.question: When large transport aeroplanes are flying at high speed, full rudder deflection would cause excessive loads on the structure. What system is fitted to the rudder to prevent this happening?

options.text: Rudder ratio or rudder travel changer.
Fully powered rudder control.
Rudder trim system.
Yaw damper system.

variant.question:
Which of the following statements is correct?

1. VMCL is the minimum control speed in the landing configuration.

2. The speed VMCL is always limited by maximum rudder deflection.

options.text: I is correct, II is incorrect.
I is correct, II is correct.
I is incorrect, II is correct.
I is incorrect, II is incorrect.

variant.question:
Which of the following statements are correct or incorrect?
1) When the critical engine fails during take-off the speed V~MCL~ can be limiting.
2) The speed V~MCL~ is always limited by maximum rudder deflection.

options.text: A tailwind with constant aeroplane mass compared with zero wind.
A headwind with constant aeroplane mass compared with zero wind.
An increase in aeroplane mass in zero wind.
A decrease in aeroplane mass in zero wind.
